Posts.Content: Hi, My problem is that I am a big girl on the one side and have had a mastectomy on the other!  All the companies do great bras for smaller or average sized women but I am a F cup and find it impossible to get reasonably priced nice looking bras.  I have been to Amoena - try searching for it in Google - they're brilliant for those built in vest tops - I've got two and they were great.  M&S do fantastic bras for all sizes - comfy and nothing spectacular but the range of sizes is good. Heard good stuff about Nicola Jane though not shopped there myself. I was tempted to try and set up a mastectomy bra company for larger women but I wondered if us larger sized ladies are more likely to get recons due to the complete lack of symmetry - I'm 32 now and feel so lopsided! My hospital had loads of leaflets on different companies which I got when getting measured for a silicone prosthesis - might be worth asking there. Vicky x
Posts.Title: Post Surgery Bras!!

Posts.Content: Hiya, you're not the only one to feel like that,  no.  These feelings come and go with me and especially now as I approach the 1st year anniversary of diagnosis.  It's been a major experience for us - we've been taken way out of our comfort zone and it's a lot to have to deal with.  I have read that these feelings can occur at any stage during or way after the treatment.  I try to carry on with life as normal, keep myself busy, and talk to those who will listen - like my husband.  There's also your breast care nurse who is there to help. Vicky x
Posts.Title: radio therapy

Posts.Content: Hiya I think either E45 or aqueous is ok - I use aqueous once or twice daily.  I've now got a lovely suntan over the area - only noticed it the last day or so cos I started rubbing the top of my chest and had to stop myself!  It's not toooo bad, and am keeping the cream going on and my arm exercises which definitely help with any tightness.  I am on treatment 13 of 15 today so nearly there - get a posh new room and machine as my usual one is being serviced :-)  I have been a bit tired especially last week - but being off work has been a blessing.  Glad you are getting on ok anyway - we're getting there with all this treatment!! Vicky x
Posts.Title: radio therapy

Posts.Content: Hiya Everyone's different of course but personally I didn't have too many problems with moving my arm - the biopsy was really sore!  They told me it would be quite numb around the area which it was, and I did the exercises the nurses gave me.  Do those cos they are meant to be effective for preventing swelling (lymphoedema). Also you may get fluid build up in the area - this is common and they'll drain it off if you need to - doesnt hurt, as the area is numb. The doctors will talk you through everything and the nurses are a blessing - mine were so supportive. Good luck and keep positive, we're all in this together. Vicky
Posts.Title: Node sampling and mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi, I finished my radiotherapy three weeks ago tomorrow.  I have been lucky and my skin is absolutely fine - went slightly red but no other adverse effects - a few freckles have appeared!  I have put aqueous cream on once or twice a day as directed.  My instructions say to wait 2-4 weeks before using perfumed products, deodorant etc so I plan to have a nice smelly bubble bath tomorrow and maybe start the deodorant at the weekend. To be honest though my affected side has not been at all, in the slightest bit, smelly!  So much so that I wondered if the sweat glands are affected when they fiddle with your lymph glands, but then maybe in the summer I would have noticed more. Hope your infection clears up ok, enjoy your week off work! Vicky
Posts.Title: radio therapy

Posts.Content: Hiya, I'm halfway through 15 courses of radiotherapy.  Not had too much yet in the way of side effects - been told no deod/perfumed products (due to possible irritation of skin and also cos of the metals in the products).  Johnsons baby soap (plain, not the honey etc ones) is ok but I'm taking plain baths as usual and getting my hair washed over the basin so nothing runs down the skin.  I was a bit tired last weekend but that's probably due to my changed routine at the moment.  I'm finding the appointments pretty quick and start promptly - apart from the first day where they give you a prep talk too.  The doc checked me out last Friday and was happy with the wound site.  They've just started putting a gel pad over the area - to focus the beam on the chest wall.  They said this is routine - anyone else get this? I'm at the QE in Birmingham by the way. Thanks Vicky x
Posts.Title: radio therapy

Posts.Content: Hi all, I have radiotherapy in the next month-6 weeks as my final chemo session is coming up soon.  I had been a little nervous but am a bit more confident after reading these posts, so thank you! Vicky
Posts.Title: Radio therapy - cream/oil?

Posts.Content: Hiya, I had a mastectomy in December 2009 and am currently reaching the end of my treatment having had chemo, radio and 12 months of Herceptin! I actually found it helped me to work through as much as possible.  I made the decision pretty much immediately to carry on as normal as much as I could.  I spoke to my boss and we acknowledged that everything was an unknown, I could not tell her how long I'd be off after surgery, during chemo etc, but agreed I would keep her informed and be honest and only work what I could do.  I managed to work through the chemo, with a couple of days off when I felt really rough.  I had an eye infection half way through or so which meant a few days off. For me personally I found being honest with my employers helped and I liked keeping to a good routine. It is really individual though - my chemo side effects were manageable enough to go to work.  Some people get harder hit so see how it goes.  ooh and I have an office desk job so not much running around required! Good luck with it and let us know how you get on. Vicky x
Posts.Title: feeling positive

Posts.Content: Hiya Yes I had that one - three cycles of each.  The CMF for me was also combined with herceptin.  I was prescribed this as I had two sentinal nodes that were pre-cancerous but the rest came out clear.  Any more and I'd have been on the harsher stuff. I found the side effects not too terrible - but having said that I spoke to someone who was sick through it!  Everyone is different.  I'd suggest taking the anti sickness and steroids as the nurses tell you.  The epi is the worst of the two regimes.  I got offered a Groshong (Hickman) line as it can be nasty on your veins, that's a blessing as no more stabbing with needles!!  My side effects mainly consisted of indigestion/acidy reflux feeling.  They did prescribe something but that tended to bring on constipation so I didn't bother with it.  Tiredness creeps up on you as time goes on but most chemo patients will probably say that.  Hair comes out just before the second cycle - my friend went for the cold cap and it seemed to work quite well though she has noticed some strands underneath the main bulk fell out, and the body hair still goes (hurrah!) I'm 31 now, so have no idea if chemo is easier to cope with if you are younger,  I'm now coming towards the end of my year of Herceptin so if you want to ask anything about chemo, I'd be happy to try and answer, and there are loads of people on here with stories to tell! Vicky x
Posts.Title: E-CMF regime, anyone on it??

Posts.Content: Hi guys, I was also 30 when diagnosed and am trying to take steps to help others especially in our age group.  I had (and am still having) great medical care but as you say, it's a bit lonely as a 30yo as most people are 40 and upwards. Big feelings at the start were why me, why now?  I'd got married about 6 months before.  My husband is fantastic, a real pillar of support - everyone going through this needs someone as their rock to lean on, definitely. I am nearing the end of my Herceptin and then it's the several years of tablets.  I am hopefully undertaking some training with Macmillan and on the user group at my hospital - I really want to give something back and create positivity out of this experience.  I'm also setting up a support group for people our age in south Birmingham - if anyone is from the area and would be interested let me know. The worst thing now is anxiety and stress over every little niggle - for instance this morning I found a 'ridge' on my remaining boob at the side - we're fairly sure it's part of the bone structure but after what I've had I know to get it checked - great, extra stress!!  I also have a lazy eye but my doc's sending me for an mri just to be on the safe side.  Great.  Lucky me. Anyway enough rambling, just thought I'd shout up as a fellow 30yo! Vicky x
Posts.Title: Worried about the assessment

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a left mastectomy in December 2009, then a full node removal op in Feb 10 as they tested three 'sentinal' nodes in the breast they removed, and two showed pre-cancer signs.  The others all came back clear thank goodness! It was supposed to be 10 days for results from the nodes op, but I asked the nurse when she was checking my drain after a couple of days - she told me there and then!  Waiting for results is horrible, the worst, but I carried on going to work, carrying on as normal as much as I could. Oh yeah the reactions when you tell people can be awful.  I think I've got really matter of fact now and people don't seem to act so surprised-maybe telling people during the chemo phase when they could see more obviously what I was going through, it shocked them a bit!  I just look like I've got a short haircut now so don't get the same reactions!  I have had more body issues what with the lack of hair, missing boob, putting on weight due to lack of exercise...but I'm starting to deal with that a bit better, and yes having a supportive chap is brilliant! Vicky x
Posts.Title: Worried about the assessment

Posts.Content: I would have whatever the doctors tell you to have - so if they recommend chemo and radio (both of which I have been given recently after my mastectomy at the end of last year) I say go for it!  Ask the questions to your doc about what will happen, ask away on here - that's what we do, comfort, advise, consult each other.  Chemo was a weird experience but I worked through it and got on with life as normal as I could - and there's nothing like the special treatment from friends and relatives during, lap it up!  Radiotherapy is still going on - I've taken the three weeks off work due to travelling etc, and so far after 5 treatments it's fine - no sunburn (yet), non tiredness particularly apart from the trudging back and forth.  Nurses are lovely in most places from what I have seen and will help you through your fears.  Ask your breast care nurse as well - they're usually good to comforting advice. Please don't let fear stand in the way - I was terrified before my mastectomy because of the operation, not knowing what the cancer was doing - the treatment afterwards is all for your benefit, to try its hardest not to let the cancer come back again.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy or not?

Posts.Content: Hi, please do have the mastectomy.  I was told that I had calcifications in my breast tissue as well as the lumps and I was very strongly advised the mastectomy was best.  It's not too bad - you get a lot of numbness in the area and I found the pain levels very low.  They were very reassuring with mine and made it clear they're very experienced with breast removal. I have now had the scar for almost a year and it settles down into a line - maybe a slight puckering in places, but no pain, and you get used to the look of it.  I assume reconstruction may be an option later on - I'm planning that next year.  It's still a little numb in places but they give you exercises to do with your arm on that side to keep it moving.  To be honest though, if you do your normal activities and are just careful with heavy shopping bags (good excuse to get a friend/relative to carry your bags!) you'll be ok. There are risks as with any op and they'll explain these to you.  I was happy that if any infection or problems set in they knew what to do, but I was ok in that respect. You really don't want cells that could very easily turn into something horrible, - please do have the mastectomy if that is what your docs advise.  It's for your health and to improve your prognosis at the end of the day.  Compared to those scary thoughts a mastectomy is easy - and we'll be here to offer advice afterwards :-) Vicky x
Posts.Title: Mastectomy or not?

Posts.Content: I had some problems with a - what I would call - mouthwashy taste in the back of my throat - I had 4x epirubicin and am now on CMF which hasn't been as bad, though I had a week of sickness when that horrible taste came back. I had a mastectomy and then a further op on lymph nodes.  Both times I was in overnight as my surgeon put a drain in and they wanted to check everything was ok.  I was told if I hadn't had the drain I could have been out the same day, but it depends on your hospital and what their policies are, as well as your general state of health.  They said usually a mastectomy is fairly straightforward - in fact they called it a 'minor op'!! (didn't feel minor to me of course!).  Ask the surgeon about what the recovery is like, if you're nervous talk about the anaesthetic, but he'll probably mention what you need to know. I went for a consultation on the recon recently and the nurse said it's not many weeks till they do it following treatment.  I think it was 6 weeks or so usually for recovery.  If you have radio they don't like to put an implant in as your tissue has been affected by the radiotherapy, so they'll do either a lat dorsi from my back or a tummy tuck (the 'Rolls Royce' of recons!!) depending how much tummy flab I've got (lots!). Hope all goes ok, best of luck. Vicky x
Posts.Title: Surgery and taste buds

Posts.Content: Oh and yes it's very quick after the chemo - depends on where you're being treated though.  Actual sessions were 10 minutes on a good day allowing for time to get changed into one of their jackets, waiting, getting zapped - the zapping lasts a minute if that!  I was astonished how quick it was!! Tips?  Lie back and think of England, and I found a sense of humour always helps :-) x
Posts.Title: Radio after Chemo queries...!

Posts.Content: I found the radiotherapy a doddle compared to the chemo.  I was fortunate that it was at the same hospital and only a ten minute drive which really helps.  The process itself was fine - they pull you about into position and you do feel a bit silly with your arm above your head to begin with, but by the end of the course it's second nature.  I found my nurses alright - nobody walked through other than the staff who were meant to be there.  I put an informal complaint in against the echocardiogram staff recently because someone came in while I had my top off - and the manager was very annoyed this had happened - they take privacy and dignity very seriously. The treatment itself doesn't take long and you get a chat beforehand and some information about what to use like deodorant etc, and a chance to ask questions.  Compared to chemo it is easy - especially if you have no side effects.  I found the travelling and waiting the most tiring aspect, but I luckily didn't burn, just tanned nicely :-)  I remember a tiny bit of peeling but I used my aqueous cream as directed, and no perfumed products etc...  Six months on my skin is very slightly darker but nothing awful.  The tattoos in my case were fine - you can see a blue dot, but then I have a couple of moles anyway so they don't look vastly different.  I figure well compared to my mastectomy scar it's nothing... Good luck! Vicky x
Posts.Title: Radio after Chemo queries...!

Posts.Content: Oh and yes it's very quick after the chemo - depends on where you're being treated though.  Actual sessions were 10 minutes on a good day allowing for time to get changed into one of their jackets, waiting, getting zapped - the zapping lasts a minute if that!  I was astonished how quick it was!! Tips?  Lie back and think of England, and I found a sense of humour always helps :-) x
Posts.Title: Radio after Chemo queries...!

Posts.Content: I found the radiotherapy a doddle compared to the chemo.  I was fortunate that it was at the same hospital and only a ten minute drive which really helps.  The process itself was fine - they pull you about into position and you do feel a bit silly with your arm above your head to begin with, but by the end of the course it's second nature.  I found my nurses alright - nobody walked through other than the staff who were meant to be there.  I put an informal complaint in against the echocardiogram staff recently because someone came in while I had my top off - and the manager was very annoyed this had happened - they take privacy and dignity very seriously. The treatment itself doesn't take long and you get a chat beforehand and some information about what to use like deodorant etc, and a chance to ask questions.  Compared to chemo it is easy - especially if you have no side effects.  I found the travelling and waiting the most tiring aspect, but I luckily didn't burn, just tanned nicely :-)  I remember a tiny bit of peeling but I used my aqueous cream as directed, and no perfumed products etc...  Six months on my skin is very slightly darker but nothing awful.  The tattoos in my case were fine - you can see a blue dot, but then I have a couple of moles anyway so they don't look vastly different.  I figure well compared to my mastectomy scar it's nothing... Good luck! Vicky x
Posts.Title: Radio after Chemo queries...!

Posts.Content: Anyone of any age can get it.  20% I think of all women who are diagnosed each year are under the age of 50 - or something like that.  I was 30 when I was diagnosed in Dec 2009, and someone I met who was diagnosed same day, same place, was 29.  I went to see a GP about something and he too said I was too young.  I felt like showing him my mastectomy scar and asking if he thought i was making it up!! I am setting up a meeting for younger women affected by breast cancer - i don't suppose you live in Birmingham do you? It is very lonely being in your 30's with breast cancer, but don't worry, there are lots of us out here, and on the forum.  Breast Cancer care do a good younger persons forum as well, have a look on their website, and Macmillan have plenty of material available on the issues younger women face. Vicky x
Posts.Title: To young for breast cancer????

Posts.Content: Oh and Lorna, no worries at all.  You'll have to set one up in London from the sounds of it... We all have similar issues, so please do share them on here.  Body image, going back to work, career aspirations post-treatment, you'll find some good advice floating around the forum I am sure :-) xx
Posts.Title: To young for breast cancer????

Posts.Content: I tend to agree with Tess and Smelly Cat Lady here - as far as I am aware, cancer is not spread through methods such as massage.  Not being clinical I won't say that is the case for all cancers, but it certainly doesn't sound right!  What I would say though is that they may not want to massage your affected side as the lymphatic system will have been affected by your surgery.  When I joined a women-only gym they advised me strongly not to use their 'VibroGym' which uses vibrations to tone you up - as this could potentially affect my operated side and possibly escalate the onset of lymphoedema.  It might not definitely cause it, but it's not worth taking the risk.  My workshops I went to recently backed this advice up - no strong massaging on the operated side. - which includes the arm, and the side of the body.  The lymph system cannot process fluids and bad stuff as well as it used to, and this sort of treatment might give it too much work to do, leading to build up of the fluids...thus swelling and pain, and potentially lymphoedema. Any clinical people want to explain that one better, or does it sort of make sense? Reflexology and anything else seems to be great though!! x
Posts.Title: Is a massage dangerous?

Posts.Content: Hiya Yes I remember that event - Laughter Yoga was excellent!!  Definitely recommend to anyone, as a great way of mixing and realising how many others have been through it as well at a relatively young age.  I remember there being quite a few people older than me there, but it was very encouraging. Support group - Sez, I'll send you a message about that.  Basically it looks like we'll be meeting in Harborne every month on a Wednesday late afternoon, to start with anyway.  We're still a bit of a trek from you, but if there are any free weekends when you can get to Birmingham let me know and I'll see if I can pull a few people together xx
Posts.Title: To young for breast cancer????

Posts.Content: Hi, I am down for a chemo made up of epirubicin for four goes, then 'CMF'.  I keep hearing about 'FEC' but not much about my cocktail - has anyone else had this or are they having it at the moment, and can you tell me much about it? Thanks Vicky
Posts.Title: CMF chemo query

Posts.Content: Hi, wow why so few?  My consultant oncologist said it's his usual regime so assumed it was fairly common. I have read up a few bits about the side effects but it's so difficult to know how it will affect me and what to expect.  From your experience what was your worst side effect? Vicky
Posts.Title: CMF chemo query

Posts.Content: Hi thanks for this!  I popped into the hospital's cancer centre library and got some info today as well.  I also took the opportunity to ask the radiotherapist as he knew about my treatment pathway a bit.  I just get the impression that everyone reacts differently.  Am a bit worried about the radiotherapy now and whether that will affect me strongly.  He went through the possible risks which was good but got me slightly worried about it, but it won't happen for a few months yet till all chemo done. Vicky
Posts.Title: CMF chemo query

Posts.Content: Hi Wow your blog was incredible - thanks so much, I didn't think to look there.  I know everyone is different but it gave me such a good indication for next week.  I may do the same and record how I feel from day to day on a blog or diary type thing.  If it is available for others to read I think it offers such encouragement and strength to others nervous about the treatment. Thanks again, I will certainly keep you informed. Vicky
Posts.Title: CMF chemo query

Posts.Content: Agreed about the wigs - I tried mine at work for a couple of days then started over-heating (it was spring-summer time) and wore a headscarf for the really bald time.  This was only actually a month or two - when my hair started growing again and didn't look reeeeally bald, I displayed it to the world!  That was a scary day but the compliments and stuff which I got really helped. Funnily enough mine didn't completely fall out, I always had a tiny tiny tiny amount on my head.  Bit like my husband who has mostly lost his hair.  He quite enjoyed me having less than him for a bit!! Vicky x
Posts.Title: Scalp cooling with FEC 75

Posts.Content: Losing my hair was one of my first questions to the doc on diagnosis but I always accepted that it would happen, so cut my hair short and shaved my head when it started coming out.  I remember the loose hair thing - really weird and like you say fascinating for about 10 seconds!  My oncologist and surgeon just said the hair would probably definitely come out, and didn't seem to know for certain if the cooling would work - they said it can make the hair patchy, so I decided it wasn't worth the discomfort and extra hanging around.  I'd agree to go with the flow, the hair soon starts growing back - once the epi finished you couldn't stop mine!  The body hair going is blissful - no shaving for months till the hair had got into the hang of things again! Vicky x
Posts.Title: Scalp cooling with FEC 75

Posts.Content: Hiya, been reading this thread as it's absolutely fascinating!  I have an appointment with my oncologist on Monday to firm up chemo arrangements following my lymph node removal about 3 weeks ago. The advice about side effects etc are brilliant, keep them coming! I felt compelled to reply as I too am very interested in the nutrition side of things.  Let me know if there are any other forum discussions on here which focus on this, but I feel I should be eating immune system and blood-boosting stuff (had Saag Aloo and something else spinachy at the weekend - does that count?) but don't really know where to start or where best to go for advice. Thanks Vicky
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Oldhat, advice received from the Haven would be most welcome!  My closest is Hereford really (I'm in Birmingham, rather shocked there's not a lot around this area unless anyone has found anything I haven't yet) so have asked them for their DVD and may see if am fit to travel all that way for a session. Thanks for the advice everyone, I am starting to make a little mental list of what to collect together to help the symptoms when my chemo starts! Looks from yesterday's appt like I'll be on tamoxifen after all the treatment as well, for five years, so will be looking into that in a few months, see what the side effects are. Vicky
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: Hiya I've been told today that I have a primary in my other side.  I was first diagnosed December 2009 and through a long story, (starting from an optician noticing a lazy eye in July 2010!) they found some secondaries, mainly in my liver.  I was put on a drugs trial, given a PET scan which showed some active areas in my right breast and armpit, which was biopsied, and I was given the result this morning.  My original, on the left side, was triple positive and treated accordingly, and my drugs trial used Herceptin, but this one is HER2 negative interestingly.  Looks like there'll be an op but the doc will call me later on once he and his team have scratched their heads a bit. The eye thing was first picked up in July 2010 which means I am thinking the right breast was there around the same time but never showed up on mammagram, or as a palpable lump.  All feels very bizarre but am clinging to the positives.  I am interested to hear about other people with similar experiences - bilateral seems to be more common than the docs care to admit.  Mine muttered today about people getting twitchy and opening up a new can of worms!! Vicky
Posts.Title: Secondaries leading to diagnosis of new primary in other breast

Posts.Content: Hi, I've got a Groshong line.  It's a type of Hickman line that sits on your chest.  It was a bit weird getting used to having the outside bit on my chest to begin with but you quickly get back to full movement.  It makes treatments and blood tests so much easier - the only problem is in my hospital the phlebotomists who take the blood are not trained to take blood from the line so you have to wait for the chemo nurses, which can add to the sometimes horrendously long wait for treatment!!  My oncologist wants all his patients to have a Groshong due to the benefits. Fitting it was interesting - involved a trip to theatres, but they dose you with local anaesthetic and sedative if you want it (I didn't bother).  Lots of pushing sensations but not painful as such. Vicky
Posts.Title: FEC with a port
